question: Is somatic sex identity cell-autonomous in passerine birds (order Passeriformes)? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Our study demonstrates that avian somatic cells possess an inherent sex identity and that, in birds, sexual differentiation is substantively cell autonomous.
content.source_2: In transplantation assays within a passerine model (zebra finch), female donor tissue introduced into a male host adopted a male identity within the developing testis, upregulated testis-associated markers, and did not retain female function, indicating that sex differentiation of somatic cells is governed by the host environment rather than being cell-autonomous in Passeriformes.
content.source_3: Analyses of gynandromorph songbirds reported that the mosaics were not genuine male:female chimaeras and did not provide evidence that passerine somatic cells maintain an inherent sex identity.
